title: Meet the 23 Lionesses set to take on Europe – England official Euro 2025 squad
body_text:
Sarina Wiegman has named the 23 Lionesses who will travel to Switzerland next month for the UEFA 2025 Women's Euros – including 13 who were victorious in the 2022 championship and seven who will be appearing in their first major tournament. Last week's squad announcement followed the retirements of Mary Earps and Fran Kirby, and Millie Bright's withdrawal from selection.
'This group is a very well-balanced mix of players with multiple tournaments on their CVs and also those that will make their tournament debuts. I am excited to see what we are capable of this summer,' the England manager told Sky News.
'At the same time, I do feel for those that have just missed out. I can only name 23, but there are more players who have been so important to us on our journey to Switzerland. We would not be here without them.'
Most of the team will meet at training base St George's Park from 16 June, but the US-based players – Anna Moorhouse, Jess Carter and Esme Morgan – will join on 23 June. Four players will be on standby: Sophie Baggaley, Laura Blinkilde-Brown, Missy Bo Kearns and Lucy Parker.
England then fly to Switzerland on 30 June for their first match against France in Zurich on 5 July. Here's the full Lionesses squad lineup.
Goalkeepers
Hannah Hampton
Age: 24
Club: Chelsea
Position: Goalkeeper
Part of the Euros 2022 goalkeeping group, Birmingham-born Hampton was selected for the England senior squad in March 2020 for the USA-based SheBelieves Cup, having picked up caps at U17, U19 and U21 level. She found her love for football while growing up in Spain as a striker for the Villarreal youth team, before joining Stoke City on her return to England in 2010. Moving to Birmingham City in 2016, she joined Aston Villa in 2021 and switched to Chelsea in 2023. She played her first senior England match in February 2022 and kept a clean sheet in the Euro 2025 qualifier against the Republic of Ireland in a 2-0 victory.
Khiara Keating
Age: 20
Club: Manchester City
Position: Goalkeeper
Keating has played regularly for the Young Lionesses over the years, playing at U17 and U19 level, before moving up into the U23s in 2023. Her performance in 2023 and 2024 led her to be selected for the England squad to play in Belgium in the UEFA Women's Nations League in October 2023. After trailing for Manchester United as a goalkeeper at six years old, she played for them until the age of 11 before moving across to Manchester City, then joining Coventry United on loan in January 2023. In October 2023, she was nominated for WSL Player of the Month.
Anna Moorhouse
Age: 30
Current Club: Orlando Pride
Position: Goalkeeper
Aged 11, Oldham-born Moorhouse joined the Chadderton Grasshoppers boys' team before being scouted by Manchester United at 16. She then moved to Everton, Durham in 2014, Arsenal in 2017 and West Ham United in 2018. In 2020, she signed with French Division 1 team Bordeaux, keeping 10 clean sheets and qualifying the team for the UEFA Women's Champions League, before signing with National Women's Soccer League team Orlando Pride in 2022. She received her first England squad call-up in July 2024, for the Euro 2025 qualifiers against Sweden and the Republic of Ireland.
Defenders
Lucy Bronze
Age: 33
Club: Chelsea
Position: Right-back
A key member of the Euros 2022 winning team, securing a pivotal goal in the semi-final against Sweden, Bronze has played nearly every outfield position, but has excelled as an attacking full-back. Having secured numerous domestic league titles with clubs like Sunderland, Liverpool, Manchester City and Lyon, she has earned 133 senior caps (official matches played for England). She was awarded the 2018/19 UEFA Women's Player of the Year and The Best FIFA Women's Player for 2020.
Alex Greenwood
Age: 31
Club: Manchester City (Captain)
Positions: Left-sided defender, centre-back, left-back
One of England’s most experienced players with 98 senior caps, Greenwood provided crucial cover as a substitute in the Euro 2022 victory and helped the Lionesses reach the final of the 2023 FIFA World Cup. Joining the team in 2014, she played a key role in a 3-0 win over Finland. Domestically, she’s played for Everton, Manchester United, Lyon, and Manchester City. Greenwood has been a standout performer under manager Sarina Wiegman. She was named in the FIFPRO Women’s World 11 in both 2023 and 2024.
Leah Williamson OBE
Age: 28
Club: Arsenal
Positions: Centre-back
Squad captain and former WH cover star, Williamson made history as the first woman to lift a major trophy with England in the UEFA Euro 2022 final, and is known for her intelligence, composure, and technical skill. Having spent her entire domestic senior career with Arsenal, with whom she’s won the Women’s Super League and, more recently, the UEFA Women's Champions League, she played her first international match for England in Russia in 2018. Despite an ACL injury sidelining her during the 2023 World Cup, she returned in 2024, marking her 50th cap with a goal against South Africa.
Jess Carter
Age: 27
Club: Gotham
Positions: Centre-back, right-back
Part of the team that won the 2022 Euros, Carter started in five of England's six matches in the 2023 FIFA World Cup, playing as a right-back in the final against Spain and ranking second-best among the England players by BBC Sport. Spending her teenage years at Birmingham City, she made her senior international debut in November 2017 during a World Cup qualifier against Kazakhstan, replacing Lucy Bronze in the 77th minute of a 5-0 victory. A regular for Chelsea, she has won multiple domestic titles, like the Women's Super League, FA Cups and League Cups, and was called 'one of the best one-on-one defenders in the Women’s Super League' by The Independent.
Niamh Charles
Age: 25
Club: Chelsea
Position: Left-back
Beginning her youth and senior career as a forward with Liverpool, in 2020 Charles had a breakthrough summer, earning her first call-up to the Lionesses and Barclays WSL 2020 champions Chelsea. With her current club, she has secured domestic titles as a five-time WSL winner and four-time FA Cup winner, and internationally as the Champions League runner-up. With England, Charles played in two games during the 2023 World Cup and is a twice Arnold Clark Cup winner.
Lotte Wubben-Moy
Age: 26
Club: Arsenal
Position: Centre-back
Wubben-Moy played competitively for Arsenal as a teenager, while also representing England at youth levels from U15s up to U21s, and captaining the U17s. In February 2021, she made her debut for the England women's team, helping to win the Arnold Clark Cup and playing at EURO 2022 and the 2023 World Cup. She scored her first goal for England in February 2024 in a 5-1 over Italy in Spain – less than two minutes into the game.
Esme Morgan
Age: 24
Club: Washington Spirit
Position: Centre-back
The Sheffield-born defender began playing for Manchester City's youth team and signed her first professional contract with them in June 2019, though she gained Barclays WSL experience during a temporary move to Everton. Having represented England in official matches at various youth stages, she was then called up to a Lionesses' training camp in September 2020. Sarina Wiegman selected her for the England senior squad in September 2022 for matches against the USA and Czechia, then for the 2023 FIFA Women’s World Cup. In summer 2024, Morgan signed a four-year contract with Washington Spirit in the USA’s NWSL.
Maya Le Tissier
Age: 23
Club: Manchester United (Captain)
Position: Centre-back
Growing up in Guernsey, Maya played boys' grassroots football from the age of four, since there were no girls' teams on the island. Eventually, she began to represent the Hampshire County team which involved regularly flying to the mainland. A versatile defender, she gained international experience with England’s U17, U19, and U23 teams before joining the senior squad. She was then invited to the England senior squad in November 2022 for the internationals with Japan and Norway in Spain.
Midfielders
Ella Toone
Age: 25
Club: Manchester United
Position: Attacking midfielder
Regularly playing with England’s women U17, U19 and U21 squads, Toone started her career with Manchester United’s centre of excellence and signed to Manchester City in 2016. She joined England's senior squad in September 2020 and scored hat-tricks during World Cup qualifying games against Latvia and North Macedonia. In the Euros 2022 final, Toone's goal gave England a 1-0 lead against Germany in the 62nd minute.
Grace Clinton
Age: 22
Club: Manchester United
Positions: Attacking midfielder, box-to-box midfielder, wide player
Clinton started her senior career at Everton and moved to Manchester United in 2022. She had loan periods at Bristol City, winning the 22-23 Championship title, and Tottenham Hotspur, where her performance earned her first invite to the England senior squad in October 2023. February 2024 saw her first Lionesses debut, where she scored early in a winning match against Austria. She's scored three goals in her first five international appearances.
Jess Park
Age: 23
Club: Manchester City
Position: Attacking midfielder
Originally from Brough, East Yorkshire, Park played street football as a youth, joining grassroots club Elloughton Blackburn and then Manchester City in 2017. A regular in England's development teams, she earned double-figure caps with the women's U17s and U19s. While on loan with Everton, she was invited to join the England national team in September 2022 and made her debut in November, scoring in a 4-0 win over Japan.
Keira Walsh
Age: 28
Club: Chelsea
Position: Defensive midfielder
Walsh joined England's senior squad in 2017, having represented them from the age of 12, and started as captain in 2018 at the record-breaking age of just 21. With England she has played in the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup, the 2022 Euros and the 2023 World Cup where they placed second. A former Manchester City star, Walsh helped them win the Women's Super League, the FA Cup three times and the Continental League Cup four times. She then joined Barcelona in 2022 where she won the Champions League in her first season before moving to Chelsea in 2025. Her standout playmaking has earned multiple awards including player of the match in the Euro 2022 final and she was named in FIFA FIFPRO's Women's World 11 in 2022, 2023 and 2024.
Georgia Stanway
Age: 26
Club: Bayern München
Positions: Attacking midfielder
Stanway started her senior career at Blackburn Rovers, before joining Manchester City and winning the FA cup three times, the League Cup and the Women's Super League. She made her senior debut for England in 2018, was named in the UEFA Women's Champions League squad of the season and was the youngest outfield player in England's 2019 World Cup squad. A key player in the 2022 Euro winning team, she scored against Spain in the quarter-final and helped the Lionesses reach the final of the 2023 FIFA World Cup, scoring in England's opening game against Haiti.
Forwards
Alessia Russo
Age: 26
Club: Arsenal
Position: Striker
Another former WH cover star, Russo has been a regular for England since she started in its junior ranks in the U15 team and was part of the Young Lionesses who took home bronze in the 2018 FIFA U20 Women's World Cup. She played for Chelsea, Brighton & Hove Albion, Manchester United – where she was awarded Player of the Year and Goal of the Season – before switching to Arsenal in 2023. She made her senior England debut in 2020 as a substitute and scored an 11-minute hat-trick – the fastest in Lionesses' history – in a 20-0 win over Latvia. A standout performer during the 2022 Euros, the Kent-born forward was awarded Goal of the Tournament and the Bronze Boot.
Chloe Kelly
Age: 27
Club: Manchester City
Position: Right-winger
Scoring the extra-time goal to seal the 2-1 victory over Germany in the 2022 Euros sealed Kelly's place as a national treasure, especially given her recent knee-injury recovery just weeks before. Prior international experience saw her collect caps at U17, U19 and U20 level, culminating in a bronze medal at the FIFA U20 World Cup in August 2018, and her senior England debut in 2018 led her all the way to the 2023 FIFA World Cup squad. Domestically, she's played for Everton, Manchester City and Arsenal.
Beth Mead MBE
Age: 30
Club: Arsenal
Position: Right-winger
Known as a powerful and skilled forward, Mead was the Golden Boot winner, Player of the Tournament and top assist (player who makes a contribution that directly leads to a goal) in the 2022 Euros, and scored six goals during the tournament. She was also named BBC Sports Personality of the Year, the first women's footballer to win. Making her senior England debut in 2018 a substitute in the FIFA Women's World Cup draw with Wales, Mead was part of the winning squad for the Arnold Clark Cup in 2022, though an ACL injury ruled her out of the 2023 World Cup. She scored 77 goals in 78 games for former club Sunderland and has been a standout player with Arsenal, awarded Player of the Season in 2021-2 and setting several records, including the most chances created in a season.
Lauren James
Age: 23
Club: Chelsea
Position: Left-winger
London-born James made her England senior-squad match debut in September 2022 in the FIFA World Cup qualifier, having gained experience internationally at the junior U17 and U19 level. At the domestic level, James played for Arsenal at 13 with the boys' team, before moving to Manchester United in 2018. There she was voted FA Women's Championship player of the month and helped promote United from the second-highest division, the Women's Championship, into the top-tier Women's Super League. Her performance in the WSL led her to be selected for the Lionesses in November 2020. In 2021, she joined Chelsea, scoring her first Women's Super League hat-trick in a match against Liverpool in the 2023-4 season.
Aggie Beever-Jones
Age: 21
Club: Chelsea
Position: Striker
Born in Surrey, Aggie joined Chelsea's academy at the age of nine and climbed the ranks while enjoying loan spells at Bristol City and Everton. Her impressive performance with Chelsea in the Women's Super League over the 2023-4 season earned her selection for the four Euro 2025 qualifying games as one of four standby players, and she made her senior debut in July 2024 in a 2-1 win over the Republic of Ireland. In her first England game where she was in the starting lineup, she scored a hat trick against Portugal in the UEFA Women's Nations League in May 2025.
Lauren Hemp MBE
Age: 24
Club: Manchester City
Position: Winger, striker
Featuring in the starting lineup in all six of the games in the 2022 Euros, it was Hemp's corner kick that helped Chloe Kelly create the winning second goal. Hemp's love for football started with Norwich City's Centre of Excellence at 10 and then Bristol City at 16, where she won England Young Player of the Year in 2017. A switch to Manchester City in 2017 led her to an FA Cup and League Cup victory, and just two years later she made her senior England debut. In 2020 she was named by UEFA as one of the 10 most promising young players in Europe, and in 2021 she scored her first four goals for England in a 20-0 win over Latvia, before helping the Lionesses claim the Arnold Clark Cup in 2022.
Michelle Agyemang
Age: 19
Club: Arsenal
Position: Striker
England's newest rising star began playing with Arsenal at just six years old and the lifelong fan worked up to the first team to make her senior debut in 2022. She then joined Watford on a dual-sign agreement in 2023, before signing for Brighton & Hove Albion on loan for the 2024-5 season. At national level, Agyemang had been a regular goalscorer for the U16 Young Lionesses, netting 10 goals in 12 appearances for the U17s and advancing to the U19s. She was called up to Wiegman's squad in April this year, scoring her debut goal 41 seconds after coming on as a substitute in the UEFA Nations League 3-2 defeat against Belgium.
Cut through the noise and get practical, expert advice, home workouts, easy nutrition and more direct to your inbox. Sign up to the WOMEN'S HEALTH NEWSLETTER
Kate puts together fitness content that covers functional and strength training, cardio, workout challenges, interviews and news. She's often doing gym laundry or listening to music.
